comments.text:
The theory is that someone buys something from you and sends you an email 
asking you to send in somewhere i.e. the UK, you agree via email. Then they 
send you another email asking you to send it to Nigeria, this email comes 
from an address *slightly* different than the first email - the address 
difference is so slight that you don't notice (for example: 
FoxBoX@example.com instead of FoXBox@example.com). So you send the item to 
the Nigeria and then the buyer claims they never received it and demands a 
refund, they'll claim they never sent the second email telling you to send 
it to Nigeria instead of the UK. Now you've lost the item and you have to 
refund the money. I hope this makes sense to you.

I remember once on Skype that some guy suddenly appeared in my contacts. He 
kept sending this messaging saying "Haha, wow. Are these pics really 
yours?" So like the idiot i am. I clicked on the link and downloaded and 
ran it. Suddenly some stupid program showed up and i immediately 
uninstalled it. My computer became a little slower but not much. So i 
thought "okay...I guess it didn't do too much harm." I also removed the 
asshole who sent me that link. However, I started hearing random click 
noises  So i checked on my Skype and i noticed that my account was sending 
the link to everyone else in my contacts automatically. One of my friends 
got caught in the virus, so i had to delete my account for good so no one 
else would get infected.﻿

+Darude The "Buyer" wants you to send it to him. The "Scammer" wants you to 
send it to him. The "Scammer" scams the "Buyer" and the "Seller" by 
basically altering the deal, lets say by the method of using an email that 
is close, but not identical to the "Buyer's" email. EX:  "Buyer's Email: 
example@N/A.com""Scammer's Email: exomple@N/A.com" Basically the Scammer is 
tricking the Seller into giving them the item, while the Buyer is paying 
for it.

comments.text:
+Concept
 I use Avast, CCleaner and Malwarebytes, but they don't catch everything.

I also run "HitMan Pro" and it seems to catch things that the above three 
apps don't. "HitMan Pro" is not free, but it's worth the money to keep your 
PC squeaky clean.

You can D/L a 30-day free trial of HitMan Pro and scan your PC. It costs 
$20.00 for a one year subscription and it will install/work on infected 
PC's, even one's infected with stubborn Ransomware.

Hit Man Pro can be set to run Daily/Weekly and also when you Boot up your PC
I have it run nightly at 4:00 AM

My Brother let his Son use his Laptop for a few months and when he got it 
back, it was infested with Malware and Pop-ups.

I used MalwareBytes and HitMan Pro to clean it up and keep it that way.

Kapersky AV is better than Avast, but it is not free.

As far as a free AV, I think Avast is the best.

I run it on my PC and my Android based Phone.

I had that happen to me too. It said I was either watching child porn or 
pirating music. Now I will admit I do pirate music from time to time but 
since I was just done watching porn it scared the ever living shit out of 
me. I was terrified that I might have unknowingly clicked on the wrong 
website. I don't really know how the whole child porn laws really work 
because I'm not a sick fuck but I was fucking worried and felt sick at the 
thought of being accused of such a horrific crime. I literally for a split 
second thought about nuking my computer to get rid of the pirated music or 
worse (I've heard news stories about viruses that download child porn to 
peoples computers without them knowing about it (the internet can be a 
fucking scary place!) but then read on a bit more. Then I saw that it asked 
me to send money to "unlock my pc" I sighed in huge relief, got on my phone 
and found a way to fix it. Luckily I had a usb drive and another computer 
that I could use to install the antivirus from.

+Kyli Rouge Yes, it would be my fault if I fell for a scam asking for my 
account name and password and in that case I do deserve to be hacked, but 
nonetheless, if I do not receive an item that I paid for, especially if I 
can prove it, I do have a right to a refund because not receiving an item 
that is paid for is one of the things Ebay does allow the buyer to receive 
a refund for. In some cases it may not seem to be fair and/or may not seem 
like I would deserve the right to get that refund, but nonetheless, if I do 
not receive the product that I paid for, according to Ebay and many other 
sites, I can ask for that refund or in some cases just a replacement or 
choose to replace the item instead of asking for a refund.

Maybe I'm slow, but I don't understand the Nigerian one at the end. Someone 
bought something in an eBay auction and then wanted it sent to a friend in 
England. He said no problem, as long as they pay postage. Then they asked 
if he'd mail it to Nigeria. If they're willing to pay the postage to have 
the item that they bought shipped to Nigeria, how is that a scam? They send 
the postage, he sends the item. How does he lose?

I understand the ones where you're asked to send money to Nigeria in order 
to get money in return, but how does sending a package to Nigeria after the 
buyer pays for postage, rip you off?﻿

top_comment.text:
One REALLY common scam that's occurring often (weekly almost for me) is 
actually a phone scam of all things.

A few times a month on average, I'll get a call (from a different number 
every time mind you, I block the number after each call) from an Indian man 
claiming that he's calling about a tech support request on my PC. It 
doesn't take much imagination to know what they're doing; they're cold 
calling people with this premise and hoping they'll either get an 
old/gullible person, or get someone who was legitimately waiting for a tech 
support callback, then getting them to enter credit card details.

Phone spam in general has been far more annoying to me than anything else, 
as I often get 1-3 calls a day that are from machines or simply no one is 
on the other end and they ALL never leave messages.﻿

top_comment.text:
I had a virus that almost scammed me. I once accidentaly turned off my 
firewall because i was trying to set up a Quake server, and i forgot to 
turn the firewall on. After like 20 minutes, my PC was locked down, and it 
said "Your PC have been blocked by the Police due to §Child pornography, 
§Use of illegaly downloaded software."
The funny thing was that the PC was almost brand new, and yes, i can admit 
that i was torrenting, but no child porn, i swear!
 The interface was really well done, I mean, this could trick anybody! It 
had "Certified by Visa" And all these fancy Certified logos, just because 
you had to pay 100 dollars to the police as a fine by entering your credit 
card number, or by using a PaySafe code.
 But I was smart enough (I'm not smart at all) to realise that it was fake, 
because one of the Certified logos was McAffe, an anti-virus program, and i 
was like "why the heck would it be certified by McAffe? If this wasn't a 
virus, why would it certify that it's virus free? The police wouldn't hide 
viruses in their blocking programs."
 And that made me think it all over, i restarted the computer, turned it on 
safe mode (where no exe's can boot up during start up" And i typed in 
msconfig to check all the boot files that booted up during start up. There 
were the normals, Steam, skype, uTorrent, and what is this?
Two mysterious files that were named really weirdly, it was a random 
generated name like sdfhwrjjwdfw.exe and ghsgwewt.exe, i unchecked those, 
went to my laptop and downloaded the anti-virus software called anti 
malware bytes, put it on the usb, and plugged it in and removed the viruses.
The viruses was succesfully removed, and woop, the pc worked again. I have 
to say, the coder that made this virus is a really good coder. He had 
locked everything, no ctrl alt del, no ctrl shift esc, no windows key 
press, no nothing. All i could do was inputting my credit card. But that 
McAffe logo was the only thing that saved me through hell. And I'm not even 
sure it would unlock if I'd really put in my credit card numbers, most 
people would try again, causing you to pay twice. ﻿

top_comment.text:
Here's a scam I learned about recently. Apparently people call, usually 
claiming they're from windows, (the call I got claimed they were from Dell) 
and that their server is receiving a lot of error messages from my computer 
indicating I likely have a virus. They offered to help me remove the virus 
at no cost.  I was half asleep when they called and so I just told them to 
call back later. When I woke up and actually thought about it... I was 
like,  'Wait, Dell is a money hungry corporation. No way they offer help 
for something like this for free. I'll bet this is a scam of some sort'. 
So, I talked to a programmer friend of mine and also looked it up online 
and sure enough. What they do is have their 'tech support' lead you to a 
fake website to download 'software' to help deal with the 'virus' but it 
actually downloads a real virus onto your system. Then they blackmail you, 
either you pay them hundreds of dollars or they leave the virus on your 
system to destroy everything (which they do anyway, no matter if you pay 
them or not). My programmer friend's mother got taken by this scam herself. 
When the person called back later, I told him I know it's a scam and it's 
not going to work. He just said, 'Oh' chuckled and hung up. The phone 
number was from one of those jacked phones that are connected to the 
internet and scattered so it can't be traced. ﻿
top_comment.author: Bunny

comments.text:
+Bunny i remembered i once got calls from some phone scam company that 
almost did the same thing, i can't remember much of it now but i remember 
they are claiming to be "IRS" and wanted me to pay a tax i had on hold from 
a phone bill i had due, this almost convinced me since i did had a recently 
buy a new phone and switched to a new service provider at the time and they 
wanted me to pay for a fee for leaving them pay.totally convinced i gave 
them my card info over the phone like the dumbass i was. well luckily a 
friend next to me told me that was a scam, even luckier, the scammers said 
they charged me for credit instead of debit so i had a pending charge that 
i cancelled quickly and changed my card info. just for reassurance, i 
called my former phone provider and asked them if they did payments over 
the phone, to which they said "no."
the next day the same lady who called me before, called back to tell me my 
card was declined, to which i told them, "yes because you people are 
nothing more but scammers and i called my bank and cancelled my card!" 
"sir, you do realize this an important charge-" 
"if it's so important, then can i pay for my bill online?" 
"no." 
"how about in person, my provider is down my street." 
"no that's not how it works sir-" 
"oh really? hows it work then? how is it so hard for me to walk in and give 
my phone provider money up front, as oppose to risking my credentials over 
the phone and/or waiting for it to be charged to my card in forever?"
then she grew the nastiest attitude and went "fine, you know what sir, good 
luck paying your bill YOUR way because if your not gunna accept our help 
then don't expect us to help you with this charge, have fun..." 
i flipped my shit and told her "oh go fuck yourself, cunt!" 
haven't heard from any phone scammers since then. but her last comment was 
so hilarious that she was trying to be so nice and then got extremely 
ghetto and uppity at the end forever stays with me and fills me with joy.

comments.text:
It's a virus that pops up every 10 or so minutes until you remove it, even 
when you're offline. It shows a flashing folder of which was made to look 
like all your drives that you'd see should you open "My Computer" saying 
that you have a virus (very generic though, if you put additional 
drives[C:/D:/F:] in your computer or renamed your drives, you can easily 
spot the difference). These usually ask you to scan your computer (fake 
scanner) and after it finished the scan and shows the results (more fake 
viruses), it says something along the lines of your current antivirus isn't 
a full version and ask you to buy the full version  via "click here to 
purchase full version".
Some advance virus actually puts all your files on hidden so it looks like 
your computer has been majorly affected in hopes that you panic and 
purchase the "full version" without thinking.
To fix this, usually you'd have to run your computer on safe mode and do a 
full system scan and remove all the unidentified programs.
You're welcome.

comments.text:
+maminals You ask if Americans know about other countries?  Americans don't 
even know about America.  The only thing that they seem to know about is 
who is the new and shocking "star" on Dancing With The Stars or some other 
crappy "reality television" show.  *sigh* Why must I be surrounded by 
idiots?  Well, at least on the positive side, I have made money doing 
computer repairs to fix the results of some of these other computer scams.

Another scam that was mentioned in the comments which is somewhat similar 
to a website claiming to be a government website is the FBI/ICE/Moneypak 
Virus.  It basically locks you out of your computer claiming that you were 
monitored distributing copyrighted movies and music, pirated software, 
child pornography, beastiality, and other kinds of really bad things.  As a 
result, your computer has been locked by the "FBI", or "ICE", or some other 
government/police organization.  These are serious crimes and if found 
guilty of these crimes, you would be sentenced to a long prison sentence. 
 However, if you scroll down, you can buy off the United States Federal 
Bureau of Investigation for a measly $300 which you can send to them in the 
form of an untraceable Moneypak from Walgreens.

These scams often rely on fear to get people to suspend their better 
judgment.  If you think about it, the notion that the government could be 
bought off for $300 is comical.  You need at least a few hundred thousand 
dollars funneled through a PAC to a legislator to buy off a government 
official (it's officially called lobbying and it's a big problem in 
America, but that's a different video).

Ultimately, if it sounds too good to be true, it probably is, and if you 
find something frightening, stop a moment to collect your wits to try to 
see how best to deal with the situation.
comments.author: FFVison

This scam is often used on dating web sites too. You get an e-mail from a 
girl in your message box. She may exchange a few messages with you, and 
seem like she is interested in you. Then she will say something like "I'm 
stuck in (enter country here) and my passport was stolen. If your are 
really interested in me can you send me money to get a new passport" Most 
often delete e-mails by the time I get that message. Can assume the next 
one is something like she can't afford plane tickets.

In any case this style of scam is made to keep sucking money out of you 
while you are waiting for something you think is coming.

comments.text:
Nigeria scams also work on the basic lottery scam, although there are so 
many variations to the scam.  They originate in Nigeria but claim to be 
from other countries, such as Monte Carlo (Impressive, no?) . I know 
someone, who is not financially well-off, who receives countless real mail 
telling him that he is a winner, but he must pay a set amount to release 
the funds. Warning #1! Then, he receives a letter, saying there was a 
glitch, and more of his money will be needed to release or secure his 
"winnings". Warning #2!  While he is waiting for the money to come in, he 
receives mail notices asking him to make purchases of inexpensive gifts. 
 He figures "why not", I have this $$$ coming in, and well he doesn't want 
to risk not getting it by offending "them". Warning #3 (These are usually, 
dollar store merchandise, and hey, "they" can afford to send these as they 
already have thousands of his $$$) He receives this cheap merchandise and 
it only reinforces his belief that they are real and true. He has lost 
thousands of dollars in 2 yrs  and he continues to insist that he is a 
declared winner.  In the meantime, he is receiving mail from other 
"countries" offering him credit cards with specific amounts  of $$$ readily 
available. WARNING! WARNING!  Now, he needs only to fill out the forms with 
his private information. He continues to this day to believe that money is 
forthcoming regardless of his bank account being hacked into, Although he 
has been counselled by many friends, family and his bank , much to their 
dismay, he continues in his quest for the nonexistent fortune.  :((((
comments.author: Cheryl Simser

Another one from Nigerian/African scammers: Once I had a profile on a 
dating site, and this person with a profile pic of a beautiful young woman 
starting emailing me and saying she was interested in me and wanted to meet 
etc. I played along with it for a bit, she claimed she was falling in love 
with me blah blah blah. The alarm bells rang, cos a real person is not 
likely to say such a thing so soon without meeting in person. Then this 
person said 'Oh Im on business in Africa, but Im short of money and have 
ran up a hotel bill, do you think you could send some money darling blah 
blah' and I was like 'Nice try you shitbag, do you expect me to fall for 
that?' I reported the profile and it was promptly deleted.﻿

Got one of those virus scanning virus software, pretty funny story too. I 
was browsing on Google Chrome using Google and I tried to enter a website. 
I entered it and Chrome shouted: WAIT, DON'T DO THIS, YOU'RE FUCKED! (if 
you wish to continue, click this button. You have been warned). I clicked 
the button and a popup appeared saying "You just got a virus, but don't 
worry! Download this and we'll clean it!". I downloaded it, it scanned my 
computer for viruses and found a Trojan Horse. I said to me "Fuck...". It 
asked me if I wanted to eliminate the threat, and I clicked "OK". After 
that, my computer turned off, and when it turned back on there was no 
desktop, only an installation process that I couldn't cancel. It just stood 
there, installing, for ages. I facepalmed for how stupid I was trusting one 
of those. Funny thing is, it's a virus that makes itself seem like an 
antivirus.

comments.text:
+BananaSlayer64 Both of those are terrible choices of malware. Anything 
that makes itself known to the user can be removed or bypassed and in some 
rare cases the user can get their own back on the original hacker. Best 
kinds of malware are the "FUD" kind that remain a ghost such as persistent 
keylogger (My favourite was "Project Neptune") or an all out RAT (Not 
something that would make the user aware like "DarkComet" though unless you 
intended to reveal that their system was compromised)

If you can get hold of a new FUD crypter or posses the skills to write your 
own then building one from predefined templates is not original but pretty 
effective. From entirely owning the system to simply targeting keystrokes.

My point is that if you happen to have adware or ransomeware, do not panic. 
If your AV can't help you then roll back, use a backup or if you really 
have to - reinstall your OS. (Ofcourse you could remove it manually if you 
could identify it however that would entail finding the probable 
persistence module aswell as whatever the genius can write)

-- I wrote that because it's midnight and I was bored :/ (You may already 
know most of this but it's the internet - the land of weird)

comments.text:
+Razer1103
I don't want to sound like I'm working for a company, so I'll post few of 
my all time favorites:
NOD32, Kaspersky, and Bitdefender.
In reality of course, it doesn't matter how good antivirus\firewall is, no 
security system can save us from our own stupidity, hehe :)

+Ben Tabor
Hey Ben. Yes, CS2 (and even Audition audio editor) is *de facto* free, good 
news for anyone who wants to try these products out for personal 
educational non commercial use, but don't forget, *de jure* it is not free, 
because:
*You can use the serial numbers provided as a part of the download only if 
you legitimately purchased CS2, CS2 applications, Acrobat 7, or Audition 3.*
So if you have a company, and use it for profit, you can get in trouble, or 
if you work as "computer guy", and install it on someones system (even when 
that someone asks you to do it) you can get in trouble as well.

Free open source alternatives such as GIMP for photo editing, and Audacity 
for audio editing and other free open source software can be installed on 
as many systems you like, and can be used for profit (but you should still 
study license file for every software you use, when you decide to use it 
for profit), that is true even for some open source software, but is 
ESPECIALLY true for Free software (not open source), where maker frequently 
allows private use for free but requires you to pay for it if you use it 
for profit.

I personally believe, morally it's okay to use pirated software and content 
for educational purposes if you live in a poor family, but hey, law is a 
law, don't forget that when you decide to go on the next level - when hobby 
becomes a job ;)

comments.text:
+James Martin
You are pretty much right. Download software only from trusted websites and 
only when you actually really really need it. Use pirated software only if 
you are very experienced user and have access to real 0 day trackers. There 
are many free and open source alternatives which will suite your needs, you 
don't really need a Photoshop, get a free and open GIMP instead, etc.
Talking about malicious software (viruses, trojans, worms, spyware, adware, 
etc.).. Once your system infected, it's no longer safe to be used for 
internet banking.
When you factory reset your system, there's no guarantee your system will 
be clean, because sometimes reset file may become infected, your flash 
drives are probably also infected, and even firmware of your phone or other 
removable hardware devices might become infected (yes, even your Webcam and 
a Printer, or firmware of your motherboard), and once you reinstall 
everything, system will be infected the moment it loads for the first time.

get a virus, it's not hard to realize it. I got a rat a few months back 
from a user trying to get my moderator account on a website. Less than 2 
minutes after the first run, it was obvious it was a rat. I pulled up 
notepad and typed "Bye bye" and removed him without ever touching an 
anti-virus.

My point is, is that if you know what you're doing, an anti-virus is 
pointless.

top_comment.author: Anon ymous

comments.text:
This is how it works.
1) Scammer  hacks person's account and chooses to buy something from Ebay

2)Scammer tells the person to send it to where he lives instead of the 
address on his paypal

3)Scammer makes fake paypal email and than messages seller to ship the item 
first and the money will come when he gets the item.

4) Person who got his paypal hacked looks at his history and see's 
something he didn't buy. He get's a refund 

This results in the seller losing his item while getting no money.
So a lose lose situation. 

Tip:Do not ship anything until you get the money, or he tells you to ship 
it to a diffrent location than his address. Ex. This is a present for my 
son so send to (place)

Hope you see this in a better way :P
comments.author: Battery Cop

comments.text:
+YesIDidYourMom
Oh, that could make perfect sense! The video implied it was the same person 
both times, but your response makes it both a scam and plausible at the 
same time. thanks.

comments.text:

The original buyer tells him to send the item to England and everything is

thus robbing the original buyer of his product.

comments.text:
First time they called me I knew something was fishy the minute they said 
"Hello".
1) Never even heard of Windows Service Center.
2) Every time I had A virus, they never called.
3) They tried to convince me that the event viewer showed viruses (it 
actually logs things programs do, like when a  
program crashes).
4) They even tried to get me to download ammy so they could "help" (another 
call said TeamViewer. They use these to take over your computer).

After the first one I hung up the second and third times and pissed them 
off by playing stupid the fourth. Now I have a recording device ready the 
next time they bother to let me catch them.

comments.text:
Many buyers from eBay or outside of eBay such as craigslist use paypal to 
pay their sellers. And those buyers send a fake email that looks like an 
email from paypal that shows you the money has been sent to your paypal and 
that you have to ship your item in order to receive the money. I almost 
fell for it myself when I tried selling my laptop on craiglist and the guy 
gave me $1800, willing to give me $200 for shipping to send to some country 
in Africa. I was happy when I saw the money in the email, but when I 
checked my paypal, there was no money. The guy told me I have to send my 
item and send the tracking number to paypal in order to receive the 
payment. I was suspicious so I called paypal and asked them about this and 
they said not to ship the item if there was no money in your paypal. That 
is the scam.

+bombbrain1 I can understand on that note as if word got out even with it 
not being true it could ruin him. 

I had a friend who was questioned by the FBI (I was there and got asked 
some questions too) because he happened to talk to some guy online who was 
into that stuff and they were talking to everyone who had contact with him.

They cleared him but then the locals (as in city) authorities got wind 
(guess the FBI was obligated to tell them they were investigating) and took 
his and his wife's kids away for a week while they looked into it too, even 
though the FBI already cleared them.

On the upside they got to stay with his wife's family but it was still 
really hard on them and totally uncalled for since they were already 
cleared.

The whole thing is a very dangerous thing even when someone is totally 
innocent.

minutes but had an easy fix online).   Every other place in town was

customers.

top_comment.text:
Similar to the government scam is the "child porn" scam.  Basically, you 
get a website that pops up claiming to be the FBI or something, saying you 
are accused of having child porn and other other terrible crimes, and your 
files and hardware are currently being seized.  You can't click out of 
these web pages, the site prevents you from doing so.  They then will say 
that you are completely screwed unless you wire some cash to this number to 
"bypass your trial" or some stuff.  As far as I know, the only way to 
escape the page is to turn off the computer  ﻿

captions.text:
• From emails in Nigeria to using you as
a middle man with crime-procured bank funds,

we count 15 sneaky, often devastating scams
we'll commonly find browsing the internet

15 - Computer Cleaning Software,
• We all remember the early days of the

internet - browsing websites honestly, emailing
friends, downloading 30 second porn clips

from dodgy websites, the good old days
• Then you get a pop-up, your computer has

been infected with a virus, oh no! But it's
alright, just download this shifty looking

.exe file and it'll clean your computer
• Yeah, it'll clean it alright, it'll clean

the absolute living fuck out of it until nothing
remains but a pile of electrified ash

14 - Online Pharmacies,
• This is assuming you've already seen a

doctor, and he's prescribed some outrageously
expensive medication so, the thrifty devil

you are, you instead opt to buy the drugs
online

• In some countries the rules surrounding
online medication are weak, so you'll get

a bargain but what will be delivered are expired
meds, or just plain sugar pills, maybe even

the wrong medication or a tub of delicious
poison

• Always recommended to consult your doctor
about what websites are legit

13 - Scams on Gumtree/Craigslist,
• This one is sneaky - you'll find a post

for this unbelievably well-priced apartment
situated inside the White House, and the poster

asks for money up-front, then you pay him
and two years later you realise, whoops, maybe

there WAS no posting to live in the White
House

• It can work the other way round too - you're
a landlord looking for a would-be renter,

one you find who sends a check with way more
money than you were expecting

• So you send back the excess cash but,
oh wait, the initial check bounced, and you've

just given a stranger thousands of dollars
cash

• Well done
12 - Money Laundering,

• This one is very much real and yet very
much dodgy - basically, you get asked by a

legitimate-looking company to let them use
your bank account to received customer funds,

then, you get a small cut of the income without
even doing anything

• Now, while this is indeed true, the reality
is you're getting a wave of crime-procured

money delivered directly to you, thus, leading
the police directly to you

• This is laundering 101, using a middle
man, you, as a body shield against law enforcement

11 - Lottery Scams,
• We all get these things in our mailbox

constantly - congratulations, you've won 7
million dollars in the Idiot Sweepstake, and

now all you have to do is wire several thousand
dollars to us in order to get the millions

to you
• So, naturally, you're all like, OH GOLLY,

I'MA RICH SONOVA BITCH, take ALL my money
• Then watch with awe as your bank account

empties and millions of dollars suddenly fail
to appear

10 - Anti-ageing products,
• This one is just sad, a way to exploit

elderly folk who might be new to the internet
and constantly yearning to get their youth

back
• Alternative medicine websites are all

too often finding targets, and perfectly willing
to send a whole tub of snake oil in exchange

for a few big pennies
• So if you ever see a pop-up with a before-and-after

image of an old crippled man turned into a
body-builder - do think twice

9 - Dead Relative Scam,
• This is the internet equivalent of meeting

that dodgy-looking guy at a train station
filling you in on a sob story so you'll pass

him fifty cents for a pack of cigarettes - but
on a much grander scale

• A relative you had no idea about has passed
away in Africa, oh noes! But they were a multi-millionare

and left you a grand inheritance because you
were their favourite nephew-uncle-penpal-friend-something

• All you gotta do is pay a little for the
grieving family and the money will come to

you - surely
8 - Free Trial Software,

• You know those times you really need this
one desktop gadget so that a sparkling donkey

will run around your wallpaper giving you
philosophical tips while you browse Motherless.com?

• But then, the software is only a trial,
the donkey temporary, but so long as you put

in your credit card details it'll be fine-
except, no, it'll automatically bill you every

month because you didn't read the installer
fine-print

• Good luck explaining the donkey thing
to your bank when you've lost thousands of

dollars
7 - Fake Government Websites,

• These are easy ones to avoid, but devastating
if you don't

• Fake government sites will offer grants,
visas, passports and birth certificates just

like the real sites, but these fake sites
will ask you to pay a fee

• And not a small fee mind you - a hefty
one, and since a good chunk of society use

these sites for personal information, it's
a treasure trove for criminals

• But so long as you're on a .gov website,
and so long as your computer is free of viruses,

you should be fine
6 - Pet Delivery Scam,

• This one exploits your fascination with
adorable little animals

• In particular the Global Pet Delivery
or Global Animal Agency companies - all they

do is wait for your enquiry about a gorgeous
round-eyed puppy photo, then send you back

a lot of sleight-of-hand questions with the
inevitable "we need money for transport reasons"

slipped in the middle
• Bit of a scumbag move, honestly

5 - Work from Home,
• I know from experience that working from

home is the greatest thing ever: your own
routine, no need to get up early, access to

all your home equipment 24/7 - it's a good
life

• Conmen know this, know how desperate office
monkeys are to get the easy life, so website

pop-ups will promise YOU the opportunity to
work from home using a few secrets

• Ones you'll need to purchase simply to
read, and often times don't exist

• And I'm here to say if you really want
to work from home - you need to find those

secrets out for yourself, not pay cash to
some dodgy website

4 - Facebook Scams,
• The amount of Facebook scams seem to warrant

an entirely separate video detailing them,
but I'll sum up the main concerns here

• More often than not, the problem with
email scams is that they came from some random

person and barely get read
• But when your relatives account gets hacked

and nobody knows it, when they post a link
to some phishing scam a good chunk of their

family will unknowingly click it
• It's a problem that continues to this

day
3 - Charity Scams,

• When a disaster happens, be it natural
or man-made, most of us feel compared to help

out wherever we can
• Scammers are well aware of this sudden

spike in donations to a specific cause, and
so they set up a dummy website designed as

their own personal cash flow from gullible
or oblivious donaters

• Like with a lot of items on this list,
it's especially sickening when a tragedy has

happened and people out there would take advantage
of all trying to help their fellow man

2 - Weight Loss Scams,
• You all know the cliche: "I lost 30 kilos

in two weeks and so can you!" when in reality
they didn't lose shit and in fact you're about

to lose the contents of your bank account
• Most of them rely on myths and herbal

alternatives with no basis in fact, but there's
an equal number simply there to take your

credit card details and rob you
1 - Nigerian Scams,

• We've all had one of these in the email
junk box from time-to-time, but it's always

the one people fall for most, and some of
their methods are quite intelligent

• I myself bought an item on Ebay a while
back only for the buyer to come along and

say, would you mind sending it to my friend
in England instead - so I said, sure, so long

as they pay for shipping it shouldn't be a
problem, and they even asked me to check the

prices at the post office, which I did
• Then they said, well, actually, he'll

be making a trip to Nigeria soon so could
you please mail it there - and that's when

I caught on, I realised they'd tried to string
me along and wear me down until I said, welp,

might aswell send it there instead
• But since Nigeria has a scam stigma now,

not as many people fall for it - but the risk
is always there

title: 15 Online Scams You Might Get Fooled By
